results.title: Beautiful people [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Ben Woolford, Beautiful stories and Jasmin Disdar
results.brief_description: The ethnic conflict in the former Yugoslavia is an unlikely subject matter for this British black comedy which uses the Balkan war as a catalyst to explore a contemporary London bursting with racial discord. The films interconnected stories are set off by a brawl between a Serbian (Dado Jehan) and a Croatian (Faruk Pruti) on a busy downtown London bus, an apt and humorous metaphor for the worsening situation. Meanwhile a headmaster’s football hooligan son, inadvertently lands right in the middle of the war, a Tory MP’s daughter (Charlotte Coleman) falls in love with one of her patients and a BBC war correspondent suffering from ‘Bosnia syndrome’ tries to amputate his leg. Cast also includes Charles Kay, Julian Firth, Edward Jewsebury, Edin Dzandzanovic, Gilbert Martin. (Award: 1999 Winner-Un Certain Regard, Jasmin Disdar)

results.title: Beautiful Lennard Island
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Yuki Yoshida, Kathleen Shannon and Beverly Shaffer
results.brief_description: Steven Thomas Holland, age ten, is the son of a lighthouse-keeper who mans Lennard Island, a tiny place west of Vancouver Island. There is a population of four: mother, father and brother David. A gracious host and articulate fan of his beautiful island home, he takes us on a tour and dispels any ideas we might have that living in isolation is boring.

results.title: Beautiful girls
results.creator_credit: Cary Woods, Miramax Films, Woods Entertainment and Ted Demme
results.brief_description: A ten year high school reunion in a snowbound town is the setting for this exploration of how men’s lives are influenced by “beautiful girls”. Piano playing Willie (Hutton), former heartthrob Tommy (Dillon), his girlfriend Sharon (Sorvino), and his lover Darian (Holly) all gather with long lost friends for reminiscing and advice about relationships. Out of the group of friends, only Willie has moved away from the small New England town and is pursuing a career as a piano player. He is at a crossroads in his life, contemplating giving up his career for girlfriend Tracy (Annabeth Gish). His feelings are complicated by the presence of a captivating young girl next door (Natalie Portman).

results.title: Beautiful dreamers
results.creator_credit: Starway Films, ONF | NFB, Michael Maclear, Martin Walters and John Kent Harrison
results.brief_description: Based on historical events, this film is set in London, Canada in 1880 where Dr Maurice Bucke (Colin Feore) is the new Superintendant at the London Asylum for the Insane. Dr Bucke, a sensitive and humane man, is confronted on a daily basis with the barbaric treatment which his medical staff use to restrain the patients at the Institution - confinement, lobotomies, shock treatment and hysterectomies. At a conference in Philadelphia Bucke meets up with one of America’s greatest writers and poets, Walt Whitman (Rip Torn), who is renowned for his avant-garde ideas about love and sexuality and understanding of the mental condition. At Bucke’s invitation, Walt Whitman visits the London Asylum and before long, the two men embark on a journey of reform - a journey that will radically change Bucke’s life forever, with his wife and with his patients. This is a story of a truly remarkable partnership - of passion, kindness and understanding overcoming prejudice, malpractice and misunderstanding of those who suffer from the unfortunate consequences of mental illness. “By 1882 Dr Bucke had removed all forms of restraint used in the London Asylum. A year later he published ‘Walt Whitman, the man’.” Cast also includes Wendel Meldrum, Sheila McCarthy and Colin Fox.

results.title: Beautiful Boy
results.brief_description: There was a great joy when number one son, Gareth was born. Very quickly he became known “Fat Boze” because he was a big boy.

results.title: Beau Geste
results.creator_credit: Barry Letts, British Broadcasting Corporation and Douglas Camfield
results.brief_description: From the novel by P.C. Wren, “Beau Geste” is the adventures of three aristocratic British brothers who turn their backs on their privileged lives and join the French Foreign Legion. Drawn together by the ties of blood and loyalty, their courage and honour are tested in the harsh desert world. This is another excellent BBC adaptation and stars Benedict Taylor as Beau Geste, Anthony Calf as Digby and Johnathon Morris as John.

results.title: Beating the drum
results.creator_credit: Fiona Cochrane, Louise Hubbard, F-Reel Pty Ltd and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: Melbourne has proven to be a mecca of sorts for musicians, with virtually any style of music being performed in clubs and halls across the city at any one time. ‘Beating the drum’ showcases some of these extraordinary performers who have migrated to Australia- some retain their traditional style, others have blended it in collaboration with other musicians. Both methods reflect the bigger issue of the cultural appropriation of music- whether there is such a thing, is there a right and wrong way to do it, how does Aboriginal music fit into this notion, and what we mean by world music? Musicians, academics, broadcasters and World Music aficionados take up this discussion through words and music. Musicians include: Xylouris Ensemble, Kavisha Mazzella and La Voce Della Luna, George Telek, Rembetika Compania, Terrasphere, Tom E. Lewis, Inka Marka, Taksim, Thula Sana, Adzohu, Fronteras, Vladimir Kocibelli, Petrunka, Tsicaderis Ensemble and Ta’Esh Fa’Esh.

results.title: Beating the clock - at work: the limits of human performance
results.creator_credit: Steve Skok, Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: Looks at ways in which people try to enhance their performance levels in relation to real or perceived times and the ensuing results.

results.title: Beating the clock - at sport: the limits of human performance
results.creator_credit: Steve Skok, Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development and Jeff Spencer
results.brief_description: One of a series of programmes produced in conjunction with the Youth ANZAAS Science Festival. While looking at the differences in human performances at Olympic Games, the question is raised as to how one person can do so much better than another and why performance times have improved so much
